cmCourseInfo.description: Exploring key themes and different kinds of knowledge implied by the notion of "learning without borders", this interdisciplinary course looks at food as a system that impacts every element of life.  It makes connections with other New One topics, links students' own food choices to global forces, and considers what global citizenship might mean in the context of food.
cmCourseInfo.title: Food Matters I
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: INI/Munk/SMC/TRN/UNI/VIC/WDW One; NEW102H1/​ NEW103H1/​ NEW104H1/​ NEW105H1/ NEW106H1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For more information, please go to http://uoft.me/NewOne or contact new.one@utoronto.ca.

cmCourseInfo.description: Exploring key themes and different kinds of knowledge implied by the notion of "learning without borders", this interdisciplinary course looks at the place of language in connecting and dividing people, places and communities. Defining language broadly, it makes connections with other New One topics, and explores students' own language experience in relation to global forces.
cmCourseInfo.title: Language and Diversity I
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: INI/Munk/SMC/TRN/UNI/VIC/WDW One; NEW101H1/​ NEW103H1/​ NEW104H1/​ NEW105H1/ NEW106H1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For more information, please go to http://uoft.me/NewOne or contact new.one@utoronto.ca.

cmCourseInfo.description: Exploring key themes and different kinds of knowledge implied by the notion of "learning without borders", this interdisciplinary course considers how digital technology connects us to others around the globe, shaping how we live, think, see, relate and imagine in the world.  It makes connections with other New One topics, and engages students' own experience of digital technology.
cmCourseInfo.title: Digital Technology and Society I
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: INI/Munk/SMC/TRN/UNI/VIC/WDW One; NEW101H1/​ NEW102H1/​ NEW104H1/​ NEW105H1/ NEW106H1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For more information, please go to http://uoft.me/NewOne or contact new.one@utoronto.ca.

cmCourseInfo.description: Exploring key themes and different kinds of knowledge implied by the notion of “learning without borders”, this interdisciplinary course looks at how scientific knowledge and technology are mobilized to deal with global problems such as disease, mental health, discrimination, economic inequality and threats to our environment.
cmCourseInfo.title: Science and Social Justice I
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: INI, SMC, TRI, UC, VIC, WDW One, Munk One; NEW101H1/NEW102H1/NEW103H1/NEW104H1/NEW105H1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For more information, please go to http://uoft.me/NewOne or contact new.one@utoronto.ca.

cmCourseInfo.description: What is at stake in achieving ethical food production, access to nutritious and environmentally sustainable food, and global food security?  Building on integrated learning from any New One I course, this course engages more deeply with such questions, along with community-led alternatives to dominant food systems, animal rights, biotechnology, and health and wellness.
cmCourseInfo.title: Food Matters II
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: NEW101H1/​ NEW102H1/​ NEW103H1/​ NEW104H1/​ NEW105H1/ NEW106H1/​Permission of the New One Coordinator
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: INI/Munk/SMC/TRN/UNI/VIC/WDW One; NEW112H1/​ NEW113H1/​ NEW114H1/​ NEW115H1/ NEW116H1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For more information, please go to http://uoft.me/NewOne or contact new.one@utoronto.ca.

cmCourseInfo.description: Building on the integrated learning from any New One I course, this course considers various language issues that arise as people migrate around the globe, including the relationship of language and culture, the question of language preservation, the politics of minority and global languages, language policy and norms, disability and diverse ways of communicating.
cmCourseInfo.title: Language and Diversity II
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: NEW101H1/​ NEW102H1/​ NEW103H1/​ NEW104H1/​ NEW105H1/​ NEW106H1/Permission of the New One Coordinator
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: INI/Munk/SMC/TRN/UNI/VIC/WDW One; NEW111H1/​ NEW113H1/​ NEW114H1/​ NEW115H1/ NEW116H1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For more information, please go to http://uoft.me/NewOne or contact new.one@utoronto.ca.

cmCourseInfo.description: Building on the integrated learning from any New One I course, this course explores the historical development and social implications of digital technology including such questions as the effects of increased surveillance on notions of privacy, open access and control over knowledge, new media and social activism, and the potential of media arts, biometrics and digitizing healthcare.
cmCourseInfo.title: Digital Technology and Society II
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: NEW101H1/​ NEW102H1/​ NEW103H1/​ NEW104H1/​ NEW105H1/​ NEW106H1/Permission of the New One Coordinator
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: INI/Munk/SMC/TRN/UNI/VIC/WDW One; NEW111H1/​ NEW112H1/​ NEW114H1/​ NEW115H1/ NEW116H1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For more information, please go to http://uoft.me/NewOne or contact new.one@utoronto.ca.

cmCourseInfo.description: Building on the integrated learning from any New One I course, this course considers the scientific debates and social justice implications of selected contemporary transnational issues such as climate change, pandemics, gender identities, disability, and pharmaceutical research. Research projects allow students to focus on an issue of particular interest.
cmCourseInfo.title: Science and Social Justice II
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: NEW101H1/​ NEW102H1/​ NEW103H1/​ NEW104H1/​ NEW105H1/ NEW106H1, or permission of the New One Coordinator
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: INI, SMC, TRI, UC, VIC, WDW One, Munk One; NEW111H1/NEW112H1/NEW113H1/NEW114H1/NEW115H1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For more information, please go to http://uoft.me/NewOne or contact new.one@utoronto.ca.

cmCourseInfo.description: Explores the complex and diverse languages, geographies, regional and national histories, cultural practices, intellectual traditions and political and economic landscapes of the Caribbean region, its people and its diasporas.  Students will be introduced to the main questions, themes, and debates in Caribbean Studies.  Lectures and readings develop the skills to take an interdisciplinary approach to Caribbean Studies.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Caribbean Studies

cmCourseInfo.description: A multi-disciplinary study of Africa, emphasizing inquiry and critical analysis. Pre-colonial, colonial and contemporary African history, anthropology, politics, African humanism and society, religion, art, music, race, resistance, gender and Pan-Africanism.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to African Studies

cmCourseInfo.description: Comprehensively surveys Engaged Buddhism, which applies traditional Buddhist spiritual, ethical, and social teachings to improve society, focusing on contemporary movements in Vietnam, Tibet, China & Taiwan, Sri Lanka, Thailand, and India.  Applies Buddhist ethics to a range of issues of contemporary concern.
cmCourseInfo.title: Socially Engaged Buddhism

courses.name: Comparative Caribbean Literature I: Canonical Readings

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to the rich and multi-linguistic literary traditions of the Caribbean and its diaspora, focusing on canonical texts of Caribbean literature.  Texts not originally written in English are read in translation.
cmCourseInfo.title: Comparative Caribbean Literature I: Canonical Readings

courses.name: Comparative Caribbean Literature II: Contemporary Readings

cmCourseInfo.description: Focuses on recent literary production, written in the last decade, from the Caribbean, insular and continental, and its diaspora.  Texts not originally written in English are read in translation.  While NEW220H1 is an excellent companion course, NEW221H1 can be taken independently.
cmCourseInfo.title: Comparative Caribbean Literature II: Contemporary Readings

cmCourseInfo.description: Describes the psychology inherent within the teachings of Buddhism. Primary focus is placed on the understanding of the nature of suffering, consciousness, cognition and emotion, characteristics of self, psychological contextualism, personality transformation, unconscious influences, and mindfulness meditation. Includes an option for Service Learning experience.
cmCourseInfo.title: Buddhist Psychology

cmCourseInfo.description: An interdisciplinary study of social justice issues in local and global contexts.  Examines ongoing and new forms of inequity and various approaches to social change.  Topics include the origins of inequities, critical anti-racism, global labour patterns, economic restructuring, gender variance, disability studies, food security and the politics of resistance.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Equity Studies

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: August 28, 2018

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Change: August 28, 2018

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: August 28, 2018

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduces students to the theory and practice of Disability Studies. Explores the history of the development of disability studies. Examines cultural representations of disability and critically assesses the ways disability is conceptualized in societal institutions. Forms of disability activism are also discussed.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Disability Studies

courses.name: Africa in the 21st Century: Challenges and Opportunities

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Changed: August 3, 2018

cmCourseInfo.description: A critical examination of Africa as a living space rather than merely a site of intellectual speculation and study.  Uses scholarly and popular literature to explore the issues that engage the attention of ordinary Africans, ranging from the dramatic to the seemingly trivial, as they struggle to fashion meaningful lives in fast-changing societies.  Topics include urban transition and city life; economic, political and cultural impacts of globalization; new religious movements and changing conceptions of selfhood; new African diasporas in the West; dynamics of gender relations, kinships and identities; and the politics of liberalization.  Materials studied will include print and electronic news media and other mass media resources from Africa and across the world.
cmCourseInfo.title: Africa in the 21st Century: Challenges and Opportunities

cmCourseInfo.description: Examines issues in community-based organizing, partnerships and advocacy. Drawing on interdisciplinary theory, methodology and case studies, develops skills both to analyze the social, economic, political, ethical and cultural dimensions of working with communities and to critically evaluate organizing practices and strategic approaches in community engagement.
cmCourseInfo.title: Foundations for Community Engagement

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Change: September 10, 2018

sections.name: LEC0201
sections.subTitle: Wild Water:  River Histories and Cultures

cmCourseInfo.description: Topics vary from year to year depending on the instructor. Consult timetable for current offering information.
cmCourseInfo.title: Interdisciplinary Special Topics

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
NEW271H1F LEC0201 - Wild Water: River Histories and Cultures Please note that students will participate in a canoe trip September 28-29, 2018 and a canoe build during the November Reading Week.

cmCourseInfo.description: Topics vary from year to year depending on the instructor. Consult timetable for current offering information.
cmCourseInfo.title: Interdisciplinary Special Topics

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to grammar and basic vocabulary of Swahili. Emphasis on comprehension and oral practice. Reading of selected texts. Relation of the language to its East African cultural context.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introductory Swahili

cmCourseInfo.description: Impact of Jung's analytical psychology, critical methodology and interpretative practice on issues in religion, anthropology, art and literature, popular culture, gender studies and postmodernist critique. Theoretical studies include traditional Jungian and contemporary post-Jungian texts together with feminist and non-Jungian sources.
cmCourseInfo.title: C.G. Jung: Stories, Patterns, Symbols
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Four FCEs, at least one of which should be in the humanities

cmCourseInfo.description: Current discussions of the hypotheses, starting with Freud's and Jung's hypotheses, especially Jung's collective unconscious; critical examination through retrospective analysis of the evolution and development of the concept in works from philosophy, psychology, poetry, ethnology, science and popular culture that anticipated, influenced or were influenced by the work of Freud and Jung, post-Freudians and post-Jungians.
cmCourseInfo.title: Hypotheses of the Unconscious
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Four FCEs, at least one of which should be in the humanities

courses.name: Caribbean Foodways Across History, Culture and Diaspora

cmCourseInfo.description: Examines the historical roots of regional Caribbean food from the colonial period to the present day, and then moves to study Caribbean food in the global and Caribbean-Canadian diasporas, in the literary imagination, as a marker of personal, group and national identity, and as cultural expression.
cmCourseInfo.title: Caribbean Foodways Across History, Culture and Diaspora

cmCourseInfo.description: Explores the complex and dynamic practices, philosophies and political and cultural contexts of Caribbean religions.  Topics may include the profound impact - in both the Caribbean and its diasporas - of Caribbean Christianities, Hinduisim and Islam as well as Afro-Creole religions such as Vodun, Rastafari and Santeria.
cmCourseInfo.title: Caribbean Religions
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: NEW329H1 Special Topics in Caribbean Studies: Caribbean Religions

cmCourseInfo.description: A critical feminist reading of selected works of fiction, poetry and essays by Caribbean women writers.  The aim is to appraise the development of this literature, situate texts within the key social and political debates which have influenced the region's literary output, as well as to consider the implications of the environments within which these writers function.
cmCourseInfo.title: Caribbean Women Writers

courses.name: Caribbean Visual Arts, Social Media and Performance

cmCourseInfo.description: Explores themes relating to visual arts, social media and theatre in the Caribbean.  Topics may include:  theatre, film, mixed media arts, the role of the internet and online publishing in the arts and the relationship between artists, the state and wider society.
cmCourseInfo.title: Caribbean Visual Arts, Social Media and Performance

cmCourseInfo.description: Novels written in the last forty years by English, French and Portuguese-speaking Africans. Ideological views concerning colonialism and neo-colonialism. Tradition, religious and secular; the use of African symbolism. A small number of historical and sociological texts are recommended as essential background reading. Works not written in English are read in translation. (Offered in alternate years)
cmCourseInfo.title: The Contemporary African Novel (formerly NEW322Y1)

courses.name: The Contemporary Caribbean in a Global Context

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Day Change: June 12, 2018

cmCourseInfo.description: This upper level course examines the interplay between wider global processes and intra-regional responses that together help shape contemporary Caribbean realities.  Topics include:  economic crisis and structural adjustment; tourism; the agricultural sector; the Caribbean Single Market and Economy; migration and diaspora.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Contemporary Caribbean in a Global Context

cmCourseInfo.description: Explores indentured migration and its legacies from the 17th century through to the present.  Encourages students to think comparatively and transnationally about indentureship and diaspora, as well as indentured migration's relationship to contract and labour law.
cmCourseInfo.title: Caribbean Indentureship and its Legacies

sections.name: LEC0101
sections.subTitle: Systems of Governance in the Caribbean

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Day Change: June 12, 2018

cmCourseInfo.description: An upper level course. Topics of study vary from year to year.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Caribbean Studies

cmCourseInfo.description: An exploration of the current interest in incorporating mindfulness into western mental health interventions. Examines the concept of mindfulness closely to show how mindfulness is implicitly a component of western psychological theories and interventions. Also discussed is how mindfulness is used directly and indirectly as a psychological intervention.
cmCourseInfo.title: Mindfulness-Informed Interventions for Mental Health
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation:
NEW232Y1

Distribution Requirement Status: Social Science

Breadth Requirement: Thought, Belief and Behaviour (2)

cmCourseInfo.description: Evaluates the relationship between Buddhist psychology and the practice of Western psychotherapy. Areas that will be studied include positive psychology, psychoanalysis, cognitive-behaviour therapy, mindfulness meditation and Jungian psychology. Comparisons with original Buddhist teachings and commentaries will be made.
cmCourseInfo.title: Buddhism and Psychotherapy

courses.name: Science of Wisdom: Buddhist and Western Traditions

cmCourseInfo.description: Provides a conceptual and practical exploration of several ancient wisdom traditions.  Buddhist approaches to self-actualization and wisdom will be compared to four Western sites of wisdom (i.e., Mesopotamia, ancient Greece, Christian monasticism, Renaissance). Includes guided experiential exercises for each of the wisdom traditions.
cmCourseInfo.title: Science of Wisdom: Buddhist and Western Traditions

cmCourseInfo.description: In recent years, the effects of meditation on the body have been widely researched.  There is an increasing body of evidence that mindfulness meditation can affect brain activity, brain structure, neurochemistry and other psychobiological processes (e.g. blood pressure, cardiac function).  This course will examine the research in this emerging field.
cmCourseInfo.title: Meditation and the Body

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

courses.name: Special Topics in Buddhism, Psychology and Mental Health

sections.name: LEC0101
sections.subTitle: Mindfulness Meditation, Education and Mental Health: Theory, Praxis and Research

cmCourseInfo.description: Topics vary from year to year.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Buddhism, Psychology and Mental Health
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 0.5 FCE from the Buddhism, Psychology and Mental Health Core Course Group.

cmCourseInfo.description: Mindfulness meditation is a systematic investigation of subjective experience.  Classic and modern descriptions of mindfulness and the recent scientific literature are surveyed.  Students explore a number of meditative techniques such as concentration and insight meditation and are required to maintain an ongoing meditation practice during the course.
cmCourseInfo.title: Cultivating Consciousness
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: NEW432H1: Advanced Special Topics: Cultivating Consciousness

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Changed: August 14, 2018

cmCourseInfo.description: A comparative study of mind in Indian Yogacara Buddhism and modern psychology. Yogacara teachings address the three aspects of mind, the storehouse consciousness, and the notion that the root of all phenomena is mind, allowing a dialogue with the modern scientific understanding of the mind in psychology.
cmCourseInfo.title: Yogacara Buddhism and Western Psychology

cmCourseInfo.description: An upper level course.  Topics of study vary from year to year.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Equity Studies

cmCourseInfo.description: Explores theories that inform Equity Studies and situates them historically to examine both the social conditions and practices that generate inequities and the responses by equity advocates. Examines texts in relevant fields such as post-colonial theory, queer theory, disability studies, feminist theory and transnational studies.
cmCourseInfo.title: Theorizing Equity

courses.name: Theory and Praxis in Food Security

cmCourseInfo.description: Explores the concept of food security in the context of equity issues related to global food systems. Students participate in food-related field work activities outside of regular classroom time.
cmCourseInfo.title: Theory and Praxis in Food Security

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Note: students participate in food-related field work activities outside of regular classroom time.

cmCourseInfo.description: Examines contemporary issues in education and schooling from a social justice and equity perspective. Engages with a variety of theoretical frameworks including anti-homophobia education, critical pedagogy, critical race theory, decolonizing knowledges, and intersectionality. Includes an overview of educational activist projects.
cmCourseInfo.title: Equity and Activism in Education

courses.name: Community Development in Local and Global Contexts

cmCourseInfo.description: An interdisciplinary approach to community development that considers the changing roles of community organizations and non-profits in the context of neoliberalism.  Examines the political economy of community development in Canada, the impact on marginalized groups, and emerging forms of collaboration across sectors and geographic (including national) localities.
cmCourseInfo.title: Community Development in Local and Global Contexts

cmCourseInfo.description: Considers what it means to pursue integrative anti-racism in organizational/institutional settings such as the workplace, justice system, media and education through a study of theories on race and philosophical tenets of anti-racism.  Examines the concept of race as a pedagogical discourse and social-political practice across local, national and global contexts.
cmCourseInfo.title: Critical Race and Anti-Racism Studies

cmCourseInfo.description: An upper level course. Topics of study vary from year to year.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Equity Studies

sections.name: LEC0101
sections.subTitle: Special Topics in Equity Studies: Indigenous Relationships with Place in Urban Centres

cmCourseInfo.description: An upper level course. Topics of study vary from year to year.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Equity Studies

cmCourseInfo.description: Explores the connection between disability and representation through contemporary social theries and methods in disability studies. Problematizes disability representation to challenge the taken-for-granted cultural assumption that disability is a problem that requires a solution.
cmCourseInfo.title: Disability and Representation

cmCourseInfo.description: The exploration of a range of African cosmologies, epistemologies, and theologies, as well as specific case studies on justice, the moral order, and gender relations. The influence of these richly diverse traditions is traced as well in the writings of African thinkers in the Diaspora.
cmCourseInfo.title: African Systems of Thought (formerly NEW252Y1)

cmCourseInfo.description: Explores inter-state relations in Africa, African states’ relations with the West, China, India, Brazil, and international political, economic and financial institutions.
cmCourseInfo.title: International Relations of Africa

sections.name: LEC0101
sections.subTitle: The Horn of Africa:  Critical Perspectives

cmCourseInfo.description: An upper level course. Topics of study vary from year to year.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in African Studies

sections.name: LEC0101
sections.subTitle: Art, Media and Politics in Africa and the African Diaspora

cmCourseInfo.description: An upper level course. Topics of study vary from year to year.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in African Studies

sections.name: LEC0101
sections.subTitle: Culture and Development in Postcolonial Africa

cmCourseInfo.description: An upper level course.  Topics of study vary from year to year.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in African Studies

cmCourseInfo.description: An upper level course.  Topics of study vary from year to year.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in African Studies

cmCourseInfo.description: Grammar and syntax. Conversation and written composition. Reading of texts: literary, journalistic. Relation of the language to its East African context.
cmCourseInfo.title: Intermediate Swahili

cmCourseInfo.description: New College Independent Studies. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: New College Independent Studies
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Minimum of 8.0 FCEs completed and permission of College

cmCourseInfo.description: An upper-level seminar. Topics vary from year to year, depending on the instructor.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Caribbean Studies

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Exclusion: 2018 Winter version of NEW329H1 "Special Topics in Caribbean Studies: Caribbean Regionalism"

cmCourseInfo.description: An upper level seminar. Topics vary from year to year, depending on the instructor.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Caribbean Studies

cmCourseInfo.description: Jung wrote extensively on the benefits of Buddhism to personal development and transformation.  This course explores the contribution of Jungian psychology to understanding Tantric (or Vajrayana) Buddhism. Through experiential exercises, students will investigate the role of archetypal psychology as a mediator of the spiritual transformation described in Tantric Buddhism.
cmCourseInfo.title: Jungian Psychology and Tantric Buddhism
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: NEW433H1 Advanced Special Topics: Psychology of Tantric Buddhism

courses.name: Advanced Special Topics in Buddhism, Psychology and Mental Health

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Time and Room Change: September 5, 2018

cmCourseInfo.description: An upper-level seminar. Topics vary from year to year, depending on the instructor.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Special Topics in Buddhism, Psychology and Mental Health

cmCourseInfo.description: Critically evaluates the empirical research literature relevant to the study of mindfulness meditation.  Conceptual, methodological and interpretive limitations of the scientific literature are discussed.  Comparisons between the scientific models of mindfulness meditation and Buddhist descriptions will be made.
cmCourseInfo.title: Research Methods in Mindfulness Meditation
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: a statistics course (e.g. PSY201H1, SOC202H1, STA220H1)

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

cmCourseInfo.description: An advanced level seminar course. Topics vary from year to year.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Topics in Equity Studies

courses.name: Food Systems and the Politics of Resistance

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Change: December 6, 2018

cmCourseInfo.description: Examines the food we eat in the local and global context of food systems, food sovereignty and food movements. Explores the possibilities for food as a catalyst for learning, resistance and social change. Note: This is a joint graduate/undergraduate course.
cmCourseInfo.title: Food Systems and the Politics of Resistance
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: NEW240Y1, NEW342H1, and an additional 0.5 Equity Studies Core Group 300+ level course. Students must have completed 14.0 credits, be enrolled in the Equity Studies Major Program, and will normally have a CGPA of at least 3.5. Enrolment is by application. Consult the Program Office (nc.undergradadmin@utoronto.ca or 416-978-5404) for course enrolment procedures.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:

Enrolment is by application. Application forms available on the Equity Studies website: http://www.newcollege.utoronto.ca/academics/new-college-academic-programs/equity-studies/programs-and-courses/ Contact the Program Administrator, Room 133, 300 Huron Street, Monday to Friday, 9:00 a.m. to 1:00 p.m. and 2:00 p.m. to 4:30 p.m. Email: nc.undergradadmin@utoronto.ca. Phone: 416-978-5404.

sections.subTitle: Youth, Community and Revolution in Transnational Contexts

cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Special Topics in Equity Studies

cmCourseInfo.description: Examines theories and practices that promote the building of cooperative, non-violent communities. Grounded in a series of historical cases studies, the course critically considers Gandhian principles and the ways in which these have been translated into collective action.
cmCourseInfo.title: Social Change and Non-Violence
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: NEW240Y1 and an additional 0.5 Equity Studies Core Group 300+ level course

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For “AE” indicator courses: contact the Program Administrator, Room 133, 300 Huron Street, Monday to Friday, 9:00 a.m. to 1:00 p.m. and 2:00 p.m. to 4:30 p.m. Email: nc.undergradadmin@utoronto.ca. Phone: 416-978-5404.

cmCourseInfo.description: Explores the significance of community development as a social change strategy, through a critical social analysis of local and global case studies and policies. Note:  This is a joint graduate/undergraduate course.
cmCourseInfo.title: Community Development and Social Change
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: NEW240Y1, NEW346H1, and an additional 0.5 Equity Studies Core Group 300+ level course. Students must have completed 14.0 credits, be enrolled in the Equity Studies Major Program, and will normally have a CGPA of at least 3.5. Enrolment is by application. Consult the Program Office (nc.undergradadmin@utoronto.ca or 416-978-5404) for course enrolment procedures.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Enrolment is by application. Application forms available on the Equity Studies website: http://www.newcollege.utoronto.ca/academics/new-college-academic-programs/equity-studies/programs-and-courses/ Contact the Program Administrator, Room 133, 300 Huron Street, Monday to Friday, 9:00 a.m. to 1:00 p.m. and 2:00 p.m. to 4:30 p.m. Email: nc.undergradadmin@utoronto.ca. Phone: 416-978-5404.

courses.name: Advanced Special Topics in Disability Studies

cmCourseInfo.description: An advanced level seminar course.  Topics of study vary from year to year.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Special Topics in Disability Studies
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: NEW240Y1/NEW241Y1 and an additional 0.5 Equity Studies Core Group 300+ level course

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For “AE” indicator courses: contact the Program Administrator, Room 133, 300 Huron Street, Monday to Friday, 9:00 a.m. to 1:00 p.m. and 2:00 p.m. to 4:30 p.m. Email: nc.undergradadmin@utoronto.ca. Phone: 416-978-5404.

cmCourseInfo.description: Explores the influence of contemporary social theory in the formation of Disability Studies and its contemporary expressions. Examines how contemporary feminist theory, queer theory, and post-colonial theory intersect with Disability Studies to develop an understanding of disability as a socio-political phenomenon.
cmCourseInfo.title: Contemporary Theories in Disability Studies
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: NEW240Y1 and 0.5 FCE from Equity Studies Core Group: Disability Studies

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For “AE” indicator courses: contact the Program Administrator, Room 133, 300 Huron Street, Monday to Friday, 9:00 a.m. to 1:00 p.m. and 2:00 p.m. to 4:30 p.m. Email: nc.undergradadmin@utoronto.ca. Phone: 416-978-5404.

cmCourseInfo.description: A required course for all Specialists and Majors in the African Studies Program, enrolment is restricted to students enrolled in the program in their final year of study. The seminar is taught by the core faculty in the African Studies Program and is designed to build upon the accumulated knowledge of students and the interdisciplinary nature of the program. Topics vary from year to year.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Topics in African Studies

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For “PE” indicator courses: contact the Program Administrator, Room 133, 300 Huron Street, Monday to Friday, 9:00 a.m. to 1:00 p.m. and 2:00 p.m. to 4:30 p.m. Email: nc.undergradadmin@utoronto.ca, or Phone: 416-978-5404

sections.name: LEC0101
sections.subTitle: Conflicts, Negotiations and Peacebuilding in Africa

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Changed: August 7, 2018

cmCourseInfo.description: An upper level course. Topics of study vary from year to year.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in African Studies

courses.name: Senior Research Project in Equity Studies

cmCourseInfo.description: Supervised research project undertaken in the final year of study. Students attend a seminar to present their on-going research and to discuss the research process. Final projects will be presented in a public student research symposium. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Senior Research Project in Equity Studies
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: NEW240Y1, 1.0 FCE Equity Studies Core Group 300+ level course, and a minimum cGPA of 3.0.

cmCourseInfo.description: A placement-based course in which students develop knowledge, practice and professional skills appropriate to the social purpose sector while working to support programming for community partners. The accompanying seminar considers social justice issues and models community-engagement practice, supporting students’ experiential, participatory and reflective learning. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Independent Community Engaged Learning

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Enrolment is via application. Please see the Community Engaged Learning website for more information: http://www.newcollege.utoronto.ca/academics/new-college-academic-programs/community-engaged-learning/

cmCourseInfo.description: A placement-based course in which students gain experience and develop social research and professional skills working on projects initiated by community partners. The accompanying seminar reviews conventional and creative interdisciplinary research methodologies relevant to the social purpose sector while supporting students’ participatory- and reflective learning. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Independent Community Engaged Research
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Completion of a minimum of 9.0 FCE and successful completion of the application process.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:

Enrolment is via application. Please see the Community Engaged Learning website for more information: http://www.newcollege.utoronto.ca/academics/new-college-academic-programs/community-engaged-learning/
